content:
hmm, looks like I find a solution for example : 3 5 5 -2 -3 -3
Am i missing something?
hmm, next testcase "careful about zeros": 0 0 2 0 3 -4
i guess i'll have to write a sim...but the answers seem to be reasonable.
I don't think as-is there's only 1 solution...I'll keep trying.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: uproved

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: re approved... my code still works in the test cases... (and i want to see the NicknamedTwice solution)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: lovely problem! i did manage to use np.linalg.solve to solve this problem within 30 lines aswell as using scipy.optimize.fsolve although my solution for that was a quite long. i still do believe that this problem should be of hard difficulty rather than medium
Great puzzle idea! I have seen a very similar puzzle on adventofcode.com with hail stones flying through space: https://adventofcode.com/2023/day/24

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i think there are very hard puzzles easier than this one.... i don't know clojure but i think the codingowner solution is deterministic.... i used newton’s method for root finding... maybe my approach is little robust for this problem, but last case reach up the solution with 28 iterations...oh remember to use a smart initial value
newton’s method fails to converge in the last cases... i guess gradient descent might be better

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

Do the numbers need to be so big? What's the point in the ducks' positions to be in the trillions when the differences in their positions is at most in the millions? I'm not sure about this, but some languages may not (easily) support numbers larger than 32 bit ones (about 2 billion).

Now making the numbers so big would make sense if their speed was much greater, like hundreds of millions of units/s, or their positions much farther apart. But that's not the case here...

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I find this puzzle very interesting and different from others I have tried.
linear independence of velocities is no guarantee of uniqueness of solution. this is a nonlinear problem i think with multiple correct solutions

Hello, this is a very interesting challenge. Very mathematical, I hope to come across it one day in the puzzles of the week. It would be good to specify the limits of x,y,z and vx,vy,vz example: -2^31<x<2^31

Cases
* I've noticed that your code contains "remove #(zero?", but it looks like only Validator 2 requires such removal. It's better to include a similar scenario in a visible test.

Thanks.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: great puzzle! i feel like the difficulty could be higher, but hopefully, others can share their feedback too

good puzzle, it becomes much easier to solve if we just use numpy.

one improvement i see is explaining what 'linearly independent in 3d space' means. you could say something like 'this ensures the ducks move in distinct directions, allowing a single bullet to intersect all their paths at different times.'

Thanks!
I agree it would be quite easy to solve with something like numpy.linalg.solve or z3. You are free to choose your favourite way.
However, personally, my point is to practice cross product and intersection line of two plane. For practice, better do the calculation manually.
For linear independence, I added a link for reference. Since without linear independence, we can still construct a single bullet situation, it just has infinite solutions.
Yeah, this is a bit tough. I'm stumped at the moment.

Good point, thanks!
I will add a test case for zeros soon. It seems my solution is not robust enough to handle bullet direction like (0,0,1) in shifted system.
thanks! I added a range.

Yes, generally there is no guarantee.
But I made up the case so that there is unique solution.

it's a way to filter out the brute force solution.
i think to understand the limitations and corresponding workarounds of a language is also part of that language. so, the fact that "some language may not support Long Long type" should not be a limitation for a general puzzle.
i'll make the solution public in python :)

tests for zeros added.
Really frustrated for handling "divided by zero" issue. It makes the thing not as smooth.
But that's life, I guess. ;)

Yup, that's life ;)

Thank you for following up!
I've reformatted the variables in Goal section.
yea, i get that. i couldn’t get numpy to work, but i enjoy doing the math manually - it’s more satisfying
I tried scipy.optimize.fsolve, but cannot make it work for big numbers. It is harder than I thought...

linear independence does not assure there will be a solution.... this case the velocities are linear independent, but not solution

2 0 0 @ 1 0 0
0 2 0 @ 0 1 0
0 0 2 @ 0 0 1
I didn't claim that linear independence guarantee anything.
